UNIVERSITY ENDOWrIENT.
PRESIDENT OILMAN ON THE NEEDS OF
HOPKINS.

Ordinarily, few things connected with the
life of the University are so remote from the
concern of the students as its finances. All,
however, recognize the fact that the money
received from tuition and fees falls far short
of the amount necessary to support the institution, and all think with gratitude of the
man whose gift of the original endowment
made the University possible.
Colleges are proverbially needy. Even the
most liberally endowed are continually seeking and receiving additional gifts.
Halls,
professorships, libraries, lecture courses are
added from time to time, until a complex organization bearing the name of one man represents the beneficence of many. The higher
the standard that such an institution maintains, the greater must be the endowment
which supports it, and the more difficult its
development and expansion becomes.
Recently the Johns Hopkins University has
twice asked for aid, first from its friends as individuals, and later from the State. This was
on account of peculiar and unusual circumstances, and no request was ever made with
greater reason. One effect of the State aid
thus obtained was to interest the students as
well as the people at large in the endowment
of the University. The unusual circumstances
will soon pass away, and the trustees will find
themselves able to carry on the work as before.
Yet this is not enough. Every Hopkins
man feels that the University should be much
more than able to pay its debts. There should
be continual expansion along many lines. Departments already organized need more complete equipment; others should be extended
into new fields, Some lines of work not yet

No. 2

undertaken should be begun. As the number
of students increases the endowment should
become larger and more varied until the embarrassment of a single railroad should no
longer seriously affect it.
For the direct accomplishment of this, there
is little that the students can do. They can
only be interested. Yet this interest, in the
University and out of it, is the very thing
most needed. Whatever they can do to cultivate the feeling that the University belongs
essentially to the State and city and is worthy
of their regard, will be of value. As the importance and worth of the University are appreciated at home and its needs are recognized, its wants will be supplied.
With this thought, the subject has been introduced. Forecasts of the future are usually
interesting; the more so in this case, because we have a firm faith that money will
conic, and expansion along lines where it is
most needed will not be long delayed. Accordingly, President Gilman was asked to say
what could be done at Hopkins with the gift
of a million dollars. He answered as follows:
"I have been asked to say in what way a
million of dollars could be used advantageously by the Johns Hopkins University.
Undoubtedly the best use of such a fund would
be to invest it and employ the income only for
the promotion of the manifold departments of
the University, at the discretion of the trustees; but if more specific intimations are desired, I should say that the foundation of ten
professorships, each with a capital of $1oo,000, would be most serviceable. But as there
are many who can give smaller sums than that
which is referred to, I name the following as
among the wants of the University:
"1. A generous endowment of the Library.
This is an object to which any amount of
money could be directed. The gift of $5,000,
for example, would enrich our collection with

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

many books that are very much needed at the
Present time.
"2. Aid for deserving students. If $1,000
or $2,000 could be applied annually by the
trustees, not as honors to be won but as help
to be given to meritorious students who are
earning their own support during their academic life, the service would be very great.
"3. I should be very glad to see an athletic
field, where all sorts of athletic sports might
be encouraged."
J. C. F.

UNIVERSITY INTENSION.
THE TEACHERS' LECTURES AT HOPKINS.

The courses of lectures offered the school
teachers, to begin the first week of November,
while comprising some of the features of socalled University Extension, as a plan is more
in the direction of University 1n-tension.
University men are not to go afield drumming
up an audience; the audience comes to the
University. The new system is designed to
break down the middle wall or partition between the University and the schools of Baltimore. It is hoped, also, to raise the level of
educational work in this city by giving good
examples of pedagogical work and representative courses in History and Science.
Annually several courses of lectures are
thrown open to the public, but the present
series is notable for the introduction of the
class idea and examinations. A fee, furthermore, is for the first time charged. With admission to the lectures is included the privilege of a final written examination under University authority, with the possibility of a certificate, which, in all probability, will be of
some real service to teachers desiring promotion.
The Scientific Course will be directed by
Professor Clark, but the class lectures, embracing Geologoy and Physical Geography,
will be given chiefly by Dr. George B. Shattuck, Saturday mornings. The Historical
Course will be guided by Professor Adams,

who will give a series of illustrated lectures on
the History of 'Education, beginning with
China. Professor Cunningham, of Cambridge, will discuss certain interesting topics
of English History, regarding the Church and
English cities. Doctors Steiner and Lee, together with Professor James Schouler, will
also contribute to the Historical series. It is
not unlikely that Dr. Wm. T. Harris, U. S.
Commissioner of Education, will lend a hand.
He has already promised the use of his collection of stereopticon views illustrating the history of European education. These lectures
occur Friday evenings.
The lectures in both courses will be accompanied by printed outlines, and by questions
which hearers can answer at home in their
own time and in their own way. Texts will
be assigned for home reading, as Tarr's
"Physical Geography" and Scott's "Geology," in the scientific course.
The project is attracting considerable attention in the city. Several societies which in
former years have had so-called extension
courses conducted by representatives of the
University of Pennsylvania, will this winter
join the Hopkins movement. Though the
lectures are specially for the benefit of teachers, they are, indeed, open to anyone interested in the proposed subjects.

GRADUATE NOTES.

Action has finally been taken on the question of social relations among the graduate
students. On Friday last a meeting was held,
and the Graduates' Club was organized, with
an immediate membership of over thirty from
the various departments. The club is to be
run on the tines of the original Johns Hopkins
University Club. Rooms will be secured at
once and particular nights will be selected for
a general gathering of the clans. Students
from the different departments will have opportunities for forming acquaintances outside
the narrow limits of their own department and

THE NEWS-LETTER.
enjoying some of the good fellowship which
was so prominent a feature in the old Johns
Hopkins Club and its predecessor, the
"Kneipe." The government of the club was
made as informal as possible, and was placed
in the hands of a board of three governors and
a treasurer, all elected to •serve provisionally
for two months. Those elected were: Treasurer, William Myers; governors, St. G. L.
Sioussat, W. A. Montgomery and V. A. Renouf.
Department work is now in full swing, and
seminaries and classes are hard at work. Most
of the new students have settled the most vexing question which first confronts them,
namely, what selection they shall make from
the various courses offered them. The past
two meetings of the Historical Seminary have
been unusually interesting, the first on account
of the presence of a number of former students
of the department who happened to be in
town, and the second on account of a lecture
by Dr. Mathews, of the Geological Department, on "Maps." Dr. Mathews had a number of maps to illustrate his points, and told
some interesting facts about the different
kinds of maps, their construction, and some
of the earliest maps of North America, the
Colonies and Maryland and Virginia.

THE COLLEGE CONGRESS.
II OUSE.

The Junior Class went about the organization of the House of Representatives with
such heartiness, dignity and dispatch, as to
melt the stern face of the iCensor into a halo
of benediction. William P. Shriver was
elected Speaker, with James L. A. Burrell,
Speaker pro tem. Reginald Ley McAll was
named clerk. The election of Alexander
VanR. Schermerhorn as sergeant-at-arms
completed the organization.
The subject for debate on November ioth
is announced:
Resolved, That the Monroe Doctrine does

3

not apply to American activity in Europe and
the East, but does apply to European activity
in America.
Representatives Anderson and Glazer will
support the affirmative, while Degrange and
Baetjer will advance the leading arguments on
the negative side.
SENATE.

The class of '99 put on their Senatorial
robes the 12th of October, were addressed at
length by the 'Censor, and in a spirited session
perfected an organization on the model of the
United States Senate.
Mr. Robert H. Grimes was elected President, and Mr. Walter M. Fooks Vice-President. Mr. Edward A. Spilman was chosen
secretary, and Lyttleton Chambers will serve
as sergeant-at-arms.

FIEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

Dr. W. G. McCallum, M. D., '97, and Dr.
Reid Hunt, are recent additions to the faculty.
Messrs. E. S. Oliver and Lawrason Brown,
of the fourth year, are both absent on account
of serious illness. Both seem to have contracted disease by over-work.
Dr. Richard B. Strong, M. D., '97, now Assistant Surgeon, U. S. A., who has been ill of
typhoid fever, at Tampa, Fla., is rapidly recovering.
Among those students who travelled or
studied in Europe this summer were the following: F. P. Gay, in Paris; A. M. Atherton,
W. D. Baldwin, S. H. Watts, R. G. Power, of
the second year, and W. P. Kellogg and H. A.
Christian, of the third year, all in Germany.
Dr. Wm. J. Calvert, M. D., 1898, has seen
army service all summer as an Acting Assistant Surgeon, U.S. A., at Fort McHenry. Returning troops from the South brought many
cases of sickness with them, and laid upon
him heavy labors in their care. He has been
eminently successful in all his work, and
everything he has done has been to the complete satisfaction of his superiors.

The radical changes recently made in the
constitution of the General Athletic Association seem to promise an era of greater usefulness for that organization. The action of the
trustees in turning over to the Association the
total amount received from locker rents simplified its financial problems, and at the same
time increased its responsibility. Since every
one who uses the gymnasium contributes thus
indirectly to the Association, the provision
for a mass-meeting, at which all without further qualification may vote for officers and
delegates, is common justice that could not
well be denied. At the same time such a
meeting will serve to interest the students at
large, and convince them that the Association
is not merely a collection of candidates for
teams. If, however, those who do not wish
to try for places on teams, are to be further interested, the $2.00 membership fee should
either be materially reduced, or else made to
mean something to such students. At present it consists merely in permission to cast a
ballot now and then in an unimportant meeting, and many naturally feel that the money is
better spent for admission to the games. It
is to be hoped that the officers just elected will
be successful in awakening and maintaining
throughout the University a vital interest in

Again and again the need of an athletic field
is demonstrated. The arrangement by which
the football games are played at Electric Park,
while perhaps the best that could be made, is
far from ideal. The proprietor makes liberal
concessions, indeed, but with him it is purely
a business venture. The advertising and the
patronage of other attractions arc the important factors. The amateur character of the
sport is certainly tainted somewhat when our
games are booked, like any other attraction,
at a suburban place of amusement, on the
basis of a percentage of receipts. When we
are able to play on our own grounds, such undesirable elements will be entirely eliminated
from the sport, and it will deserve and receive
heartier support. Athletics at Hopkins will
always be hampered until we have a wellequipped field.
There are many who have looked longingly
at the advantages offered by the regular
courses of the University, but who, for one
reason or another, have not been able to enjoy
them. Still others look forward to college
courses, but are not able to undertake them
now. Many of both these classes are teachers in the public schools of the city. For the
sake of such persons, the authorities have
planned a new departure described in another column under the title "University Intension." The plan is especially significant
because of its possibilities.
Should the experience of the first year warrant it, no doubt the scope of the courses will
be widened. The advantage of this plan over
the culture courses that are carried on by correspondence and magazine articles, is in the
personal contact with the lecturers and the
acquaintance thus gained with University
methods. The men in charge of the 'movement are abundantly able to make it interesting, and it is safe to predict that the courses
will be widely appreciated.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
AFFAIRS OF A FORTNIGHT.
Hazing at Hopkins seems to have become
a tradition. This certainly ought to be a matter of thanksgiving to the Faculty--and to the
Freshmen. Whether the new Decalogue of
the President had a subduing effect on the
Juniors, or whether that class feels it got sufficient glory out of its hippodrome performance of last winter, does not appear. But
who can tell what a day may bring forth—or
a Freshman banquet!
The College 'Congress has convened. Junior M. C's and Senior 'Senators are expanding
with the Republic, while Freshmen are building political fences in anticipation of Congressional honors next year. That all of this
is part and parcel of a graded and required
three years' course in Public Speaking is a
happy and significant omen in our college life.
The making of such a course effective, and at
the same time interesting, has been a nut to
crack. With accustomed painstaking Johns
Hopkins seems to have hammered out the
kernel.
The policeman is a much abused factor in
the community. But there is a limit of endurance in every man's make-up. Rather
unfortunately two upper-classmen had to run
up against this limit the afternoon of the
Princeton-M. A. C. game. The Squire said
"two-fiff," and was immutable. Policemen
should not be imposed upon; still, the man
of the baton and brass buttons, with his high
order of intelligence, ought to recognize that
college men have certain rights and privileges
of citizenship extra ordinem, and that this is
especially true of Seniors. Of course, if there
must be a moral:
DON'T guy the cop.
The lunch-room has passed from the hands
of one Harris to the gentle keep of the
Woman's Industrial Exchange. The new
service, though somewhat primitive, is
prompt, and the fare is homelike .A few more

;

•

5

hot dishes on the calendar would be timely; a
modest oyster stew at popular prices would
help out wonderfully, for the cold lunch is a
real demoralizer to the average student's
stomach. Cold lunches and scholarship seem
not to be nearly related, but as old Dr. Johnson bluntly remarked (we thank thee, Boswell), "I look upon it, that he who does not
mind his belly will hardly mind anything
else."
There are some men about the University
who seem to get a good deal of satisfaction in
finding fault with—well, anything and everything. They are men who lounge at the cage
door, hands in pockets, and "damn" the athletes; the men who do not write for the NEWSLETTER, borrow another fellow's paper, and
criticize it; in brief, they are the chronic kickers. It is too bad. Such men call for our
commiseration. The cheerful thing to do is
to be happy. And the way to be happy is to
be up and doing, not fault-finding.
A course in public speaking has been arranged for the graduate students. They arc
to be congratulated. It is nothing new under
the sun: that university men are going into
professions and professorships without knowing how to talk. A platform lecture by a
flowering Ph. D. is too often eyed askance as
an evening of mental lassitude for the audience. Even class-room lectures have been
known to become wearisome! May the
words of the lusty old Poet-King early be
quoted for the graduate students: "Let me
hear thy voice, for thy voice is sweet."
The University Glee 'Club will hold its next
trial Thursday, ,October 27. At the preliminary meeting 28 candidates were present,
and the outlook is most encouraging. Some
time in November the final trials will be held,
and the club will be chosen. Mr. Louis
Fisher, leader of Fisher's orchestra, is directing the club, of which Mr. Karl Jungbluth is
leader.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLETICS.
FOOT BALL.

HOPKINS, 23; ROCKHILL, 0.
A crowd of about twenty-five rooters accompanied the football team to Ellicott City
on the 15th, and witnessed the first of the long
string of victories which the NEWS-LETTER
hopes to record for this year. Although it
was the opening game of the season, the team
made a good showing, aside from a tendency
to fumble, which several times gave the ball
to Rockhill.
After chasing a cow and other live stock
from the field, the teams lined up. Rockhill
kicked off, but Bouchelle fumbled, and was
downed on the 15-yard line. After a few
gains by the Hopkins backs, Rockhill lost io
yards on off-side play, and from this time the
ball was advanced steadily up the field. Hopkins kicked, and it was Rockhill's ball on their
m-yard line. Here our line demonstrated the
ease with which they could hold their opponents, as, after being pushed back 5 yards,
Rockhill lost the ball on downs. Here Hopkins fumbled, lost the ball on downs, and
Rockhill gained 40 yards. In the next few
minutes the ball changed hands frequently,
until finally Rockhill kicked out of bounds.
Hopkins now made steady gains, L. E. Griffin at last scoring a touchdown after a run of
30 yards. Hopkins punted out, but Mullen
missed the catch. Score, 5-0. After a few
minutes' more play the half ended, with the
ball in Rockhill's territory.
From this time on Hopkins proved that
they were in a class by themselves, as far as
Rockhill was concerned. After five minutes,
the ball was carried up the field by E. J. Griffin, until within three yards of the goal. At
this point Griffin was injured, but resumed his
place, and on the next play he carried the ball
across the line for a touchdown. Robinson
kicked goal. Score, 11-0.
Rockhill kicked off, and, after a long gain
by Mullen, Underwood left the game with an

injured knee. Hopkins was now gaining
steadily, and in a few minutes Guggenheimer
made another touchdown. Hopkins punted
out, and Robinson kicked goal.
Griffin and Guggenheimer were now given
the ball alternately, until it was far into Rockhill's territory, and then Robinson scored the
last touchdown, and once more kicked goal.
Score, 23-0.

B. M. C., 0.

At Electric Park, on last Saturday, one of
the best teams Hopkins ever had, defeated the
Baltimore 'Medical College in a well-played
game. Armstrong kicked off for Hopkins;
Conley caught the ball and ran, but was
downed promptly, giving us a gain of 30 yards
to start with. This distance was steadily increased until Riggs, by a very pretty run,
scored the first touchdown. Robinson kicked
goal. When the ball was put into play, Guggenheimer got it and made the star play of the
game, a run of 85 yards down the field. Hopkins now started in with a rush, but an unlucky fumble gave B. M. C. the ball. The
doctors tried hard to push through our centre, but failed to gain an inch. Guggenheimer
again got the ball and made a run of 40 yards
around the left. Time was now called for the
first. half. Hopkins, 6; B. M. C., o.
The Medical College boys kicked off, and
we gained 25 yards. Riggs next took the ball
around right end for another touchdown,
Robinson kicking goal.

HOPKINS, 0; D. A. C., 12.

I

The game played October 19 between Hopkins and the Druid Athletic Club resulted in
a surprise, especially to those not closely associated with either team. Attention has been
called to the fact that the team which played
for D. A. C. was composed of men from no
less than three local organizations, in which
respect it is said the rules of the Amateur
Athletic Union suffered fracture. At all
events, they had a well-balanced team, which
put up a good game, making very few bad
plays. The best work was done by Lawrence
and Lee.
The Hopkins team, though good in places,
for the most part played very poorly. The
backs missed the ball almost every time it was
passed to them. The line, too, was very weak
at times, and should have gotten into the game
in much better style. A few men, among
them Robinson, Smith and Guggenheimer,
did good work for Hopkins.

7

THE MASS MEETINGS.

A meeting of the General Athletic Association was held on October 13, in Hopkins
Hall. The president of the Association, Dr.
Renouf, presided. Nominations for the offices to be filled at the annual elections were
made, and a number of amendments to the
Constitution were proposed by Mr. R. H.
Grimes. These were posted for a week, and
after an outline had been given of the more
important matters to come up before the Association during the year, the meeting adjourned.
On the 2ist another meeting was held. The
amendments to the Constitution were unanimously adopted. They provide that the board
of directors shall consist of a member from the
faculty, who shall have the power of absolute
veto; of one delegate each from the graduate
department and the Medical School; of an
alumnus, not at present a member of the
University; and of a secretary and a treasurer. The seniors are to have two delegates
to the board, the juniors two, and the freshmen one. All of these are to be elected at a
mass meeting to be held prior to October 15
of each year. At this first meeting all members of the University shall have the right to
vote; at the subsequent meetings, only members of the Association. Another amendment provides that no one shall hold two of
the offices of the Association, which are open
to popular election.
The elections resulted as follows: Faculty
member, Dr. Rcnouf; president, William H.
Maddren ; vice-president, Thomas Fitzgerald;
secretary, Z. M. Ballard; treasurer, R. T.
Abercrombie; graduate, G. L. Radcliffe; Medical School, C. W. Ottley; alumnus, Mr. Wm.
Hilles, '89; class delegates, '99, Grimes and
Knapp; two, Schriver and Wirt; 1901,
Diggs.
For a long time past there has been need of
more effective cheering by supporters of the
various teams. The importance of this can
hardly be overestimated as an incentive to the
men in the field to work and win games.

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

There has been no organized yelling for a long
time. It was in recognition of these facts
a motion was made and carried, without a dissenting voice, that Mr. Stephen Harwood
should be appointed "Chief Rooter," or leader
of cheering.
CLASS ELECTIONS.

The undergraduates have elected class officers for the new year. John C. French was
named as president by the Seniors, with
Henry Bogue as vice-president; John R.
Gemmil, treasurer; Walter M. Krager, secretary; Geo. D. Davidson, poet. French led his
class in the junior year, was elected editor-inchief of The Hullabaloo, and is editor-in-chief
of the NEWS-LETTER.
Christopher T. Clark, of Washington,
elected president of the Junior Class, has been
active in athletics as a runner and distance
juniper. John P. Hill was chosen vice-president; Howard Baetjer, secretary; Ronald T.
Abercrombie, treasurer; William P. Shriver,
historian, and Carol Wight, class poet. Executive committee: James L. A. Burrell,
Harry Wright, Alex. Van R. Schermerhorn,
James H. Brady, Jr., T. N. DeL. Purcell.
S. H. Byrne, elected president of the Freshman Class, graduated from the City College,
where he was prominent as a leader and organizer of the athletic interests. He is the
University correspondent for the American.
The remaining officers of the class will be
chosen at a forthcoming meeting.
HENRY P. MUTER.

Henry P. Shuter, '97, a member of the famous Astor Mountain Battery of Volunteers,
died at sea, October 17, on the transport Rio
de Janeiro, returning from Manila. Of splendid physique, Ile was the fourth selected from
400 candidates for enlistment in a competitive
examination. Three days after the battle of
Manila he wrote that his battery had served
as General Merritt's body guard, and that he
had fought in the front ranks. Sinner was a
popular man in his class; played on the 'Varsity football team, and was editor-in-chief of
the '97 Hullabaloo.

INTERCESSIONAL.

Board of our fathers known of old—
Board of the sons that have gone before—
Beneath whose awful hand we hold
Degrees and scholarships galore—
Be with us yet—be with us yet,
Lest we forget—lest we forget.
"A. B.'s" and "Ph. D.'s" depart
To try their fate for good or bad—
Still stands thine ancient sacrifice,
An humble, contrite "Prep-school" lad.
Judge of the "Sub-fresh," spare us yet,
Lest we forget—lest we forget.
From the Registrar we wend our way—
He's dimmed the goal of our desire—
Lo! all our hopes of yesterday
Are one with Nineveh and Tyre.
Board of our fathers, spare us yet,
Lest we forget—lest we forget.
If, after having passed, we loose
Wild tongues that have not thee in awe,
Such language as the Seniors use,
Or lesser breeds, who know no law—
Be with us yet—be with us yet,
Lest we forget—lest we forget.
For frantic head that puts its trust
In "cramming" and through "cribs" has
soared,
And, passing, calls not thee to pass,
Thy mercy on thy victims, Board.
Amen.
1901.
A QUANDARY.

For weal or woe—
Which shall it be?
With one, a-cycling I may go
For weal or woe;
A horse doth bring another beau
To ride with me;
For wheel or whoa—
Which shall it be?

UNIVERSITY ENDOWrIENT.
PRESIDENT OILMAN ON THE NEEDS OF
HOPKINS.

Ordinarily, few things connected with the
life of the University are so remote from the
concern of the students as its finances. All,
however, recognize the fact that the money
received from tuition and fees falls far short
of the amount necessary to support the institution, and all think with gratitude of the
man whose gift of the original endowment
made the University possible.
Colleges are proverbially needy. Even the
most liberally endowed are continually seeking and receiving additional gifts.
Halls,
professorships, libraries, lecture courses are
added from time to time, until a complex organization bearing the name of one man represents the beneficence of many. The higher
the standard that such an institution maintains, the greater must be the endowment
which supports it, and the more difficult its
development and expansion becomes.
Recently the Johns Hopkins University has
twice asked for aid, first from its friends as individuals, and later from the State. This was
on account of peculiar and unusual circumstances, and no request was ever made with
greater reason. One effect of the State aid
thus obtained was to interest the students as
well as the people at large in the endowment
of the University. The unusual circumstances
will soon pass away, and the trustees will find
themselves able to carry on the work as before.
Yet this is not enough. Every Hopkins
man feels that the University should be much
more than able to pay its debts. There should
be continual expansion along many lines. Departments already organized need more complete equipment; others should be extended
into new fields, Some lines of work not yet

No. 2

undertaken should be begun. As the number
of students increases the endowment should
become larger and more varied until the embarrassment of a single railroad should no
longer seriously affect it.
For the direct accomplishment of this, there
is little that the students can do. They can
only be interested. Yet this interest, in the
University and out of it, is the very thing
most needed. Whatever they can do to cultivate the feeling that the University belongs
essentially to the State and city and is worthy
of their regard, will be of value. As the importance and worth of the University are appreciated at home and its needs are recognized, its wants will be supplied.
With this thought, the subject has been introduced. Forecasts of the future are usually
interesting; the more so in this case, because we have a firm faith that money will
conic, and expansion along lines where it is
most needed will not be long delayed. Accordingly, President Gilman was asked to say
what could be done at Hopkins with the gift
of a million dollars. He answered as follows:
"I have been asked to say in what way a
million of dollars could be used advantageously by the Johns Hopkins University.
Undoubtedly the best use of such a fund would
be to invest it and employ the income only for
the promotion of the manifold departments of
the University, at the discretion of the trustees; but if more specific intimations are desired, I should say that the foundation of ten
professorships, each with a capital of $1oo,000, would be most serviceable. But as there
are many who can give smaller sums than that
which is referred to, I name the following as
among the wants of the University:
"1. A generous endowment of the Library.
This is an object to which any amount of
money could be directed. The gift of $5,000,
for example, would enrich our collection with

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

many books that are very much needed at the
Present time.
"2. Aid for deserving students. If $1,000
or $2,000 could be applied annually by the
trustees, not as honors to be won but as help
to be given to meritorious students who are
earning their own support during their academic life, the service would be very great.
"3. I should be very glad to see an athletic
field, where all sorts of athletic sports might
be encouraged."
J. C. F.

UNIVERSITY INTENSION.
THE TEACHERS' LECTURES AT HOPKINS.

The courses of lectures offered the school
teachers, to begin the first week of November,
while comprising some of the features of socalled University Extension, as a plan is more
in the direction of University 1n-tension.
University men are not to go afield drumming
up an audience; the audience comes to the
University. The new system is designed to
break down the middle wall or partition between the University and the schools of Baltimore. It is hoped, also, to raise the level of
educational work in this city by giving good
examples of pedagogical work and representative courses in History and Science.
Annually several courses of lectures are
thrown open to the public, but the present
series is notable for the introduction of the
class idea and examinations. A fee, furthermore, is for the first time charged. With admission to the lectures is included the privilege of a final written examination under University authority, with the possibility of a certificate, which, in all probability, will be of
some real service to teachers desiring promotion.
The Scientific Course will be directed by
Professor Clark, but the class lectures, embracing Geologoy and Physical Geography,
will be given chiefly by Dr. George B. Shattuck, Saturday mornings. The Historical
Course will be guided by Professor Adams,

who will give a series of illustrated lectures on
the History of 'Education, beginning with
China. Professor Cunningham, of Cambridge, will discuss certain interesting topics
of English History, regarding the Church and
English cities. Doctors Steiner and Lee, together with Professor James Schouler, will
also contribute to the Historical series. It is
not unlikely that Dr. Wm. T. Harris, U. S.
Commissioner of Education, will lend a hand.
He has already promised the use of his collection of stereopticon views illustrating the history of European education. These lectures
occur Friday evenings.
The lectures in both courses will be accompanied by printed outlines, and by questions
which hearers can answer at home in their
own time and in their own way. Texts will
be assigned for home reading, as Tarr's
"Physical Geography" and Scott's "Geology," in the scientific course.
The project is attracting considerable attention in the city. Several societies which in
former years have had so-called extension
courses conducted by representatives of the
University of Pennsylvania, will this winter
join the Hopkins movement. Though the
lectures are specially for the benefit of teachers, they are, indeed, open to anyone interested in the proposed subjects.

GRADUATE NOTES.

Action has finally been taken on the question of social relations among the graduate
students. On Friday last a meeting was held,
and the Graduates' Club was organized, with
an immediate membership of over thirty from
the various departments. The club is to be
run on the tines of the original Johns Hopkins
University Club. Rooms will be secured at
once and particular nights will be selected for
a general gathering of the clans. Students
from the different departments will have opportunities for forming acquaintances outside
the narrow limits of their own department and

THE NEWS-LETTER.
enjoying some of the good fellowship which
was so prominent a feature in the old Johns
Hopkins Club and its predecessor, the
"Kneipe." The government of the club was
made as informal as possible, and was placed
in the hands of a board of three governors and
a treasurer, all elected to •serve provisionally
for two months. Those elected were: Treasurer, William Myers; governors, St. G. L.
Sioussat, W. A. Montgomery and V. A. Renouf.
Department work is now in full swing, and
seminaries and classes are hard at work. Most
of the new students have settled the most vexing question which first confronts them,
namely, what selection they shall make from
the various courses offered them. The past
two meetings of the Historical Seminary have
been unusually interesting, the first on account
of the presence of a number of former students
of the department who happened to be in
town, and the second on account of a lecture
by Dr. Mathews, of the Geological Department, on "Maps." Dr. Mathews had a number of maps to illustrate his points, and told
some interesting facts about the different
kinds of maps, their construction, and some
of the earliest maps of North America, the
Colonies and Maryland and Virginia.

THE COLLEGE CONGRESS.
II OUSE.

The Junior Class went about the organization of the House of Representatives with
such heartiness, dignity and dispatch, as to
melt the stern face of the iCensor into a halo
of benediction. William P. Shriver was
elected Speaker, with James L. A. Burrell,
Speaker pro tem. Reginald Ley McAll was
named clerk. The election of Alexander
VanR. Schermerhorn as sergeant-at-arms
completed the organization.
The subject for debate on November ioth
is announced:
Resolved, That the Monroe Doctrine does

3

not apply to American activity in Europe and
the East, but does apply to European activity
in America.
Representatives Anderson and Glazer will
support the affirmative, while Degrange and
Baetjer will advance the leading arguments on
the negative side.
SENATE.

The class of '99 put on their Senatorial
robes the 12th of October, were addressed at
length by the 'Censor, and in a spirited session
perfected an organization on the model of the
United States Senate.
Mr. Robert H. Grimes was elected President, and Mr. Walter M. Fooks Vice-President. Mr. Edward A. Spilman was chosen
secretary, and Lyttleton Chambers will serve
as sergeant-at-arms.

FIEDICAL SCHOOL NOTES.

Dr. W. G. McCallum, M. D., '97, and Dr.
Reid Hunt, are recent additions to the faculty.
Messrs. E. S. Oliver and Lawrason Brown,
of the fourth year, are both absent on account
of serious illness. Both seem to have contracted disease by over-work.
Dr. Richard B. Strong, M. D., '97, now Assistant Surgeon, U. S. A., who has been ill of
typhoid fever, at Tampa, Fla., is rapidly recovering.
Among those students who travelled or
studied in Europe this summer were the following: F. P. Gay, in Paris; A. M. Atherton,
W. D. Baldwin, S. H. Watts, R. G. Power, of
the second year, and W. P. Kellogg and H. A.
Christian, of the third year, all in Germany.
Dr. Wm. J. Calvert, M. D., 1898, has seen
army service all summer as an Acting Assistant Surgeon, U.S. A., at Fort McHenry. Returning troops from the South brought many
cases of sickness with them, and laid upon
him heavy labors in their care. He has been
eminently successful in all his work, and
everything he has done has been to the complete satisfaction of his superiors.

The radical changes recently made in the
constitution of the General Athletic Association seem to promise an era of greater usefulness for that organization. The action of the
trustees in turning over to the Association the
total amount received from locker rents simplified its financial problems, and at the same
time increased its responsibility. Since every
one who uses the gymnasium contributes thus
indirectly to the Association, the provision
for a mass-meeting, at which all without further qualification may vote for officers and
delegates, is common justice that could not
well be denied. At the same time such a
meeting will serve to interest the students at
large, and convince them that the Association
is not merely a collection of candidates for
teams. If, however, those who do not wish
to try for places on teams, are to be further interested, the $2.00 membership fee should
either be materially reduced, or else made to
mean something to such students. At present it consists merely in permission to cast a
ballot now and then in an unimportant meeting, and many naturally feel that the money is
better spent for admission to the games. It
is to be hoped that the officers just elected will
be successful in awakening and maintaining
throughout the University a vital interest in

Again and again the need of an athletic field
is demonstrated. The arrangement by which
the football games are played at Electric Park,
while perhaps the best that could be made, is
far from ideal. The proprietor makes liberal
concessions, indeed, but with him it is purely
a business venture. The advertising and the
patronage of other attractions arc the important factors. The amateur character of the
sport is certainly tainted somewhat when our
games are booked, like any other attraction,
at a suburban place of amusement, on the
basis of a percentage of receipts. When we
are able to play on our own grounds, such undesirable elements will be entirely eliminated
from the sport, and it will deserve and receive
heartier support. Athletics at Hopkins will
always be hampered until we have a wellequipped field.
There are many who have looked longingly
at the advantages offered by the regular
courses of the University, but who, for one
reason or another, have not been able to enjoy
them. Still others look forward to college
courses, but are not able to undertake them
now. Many of both these classes are teachers in the public schools of the city. For the
sake of such persons, the authorities have
planned a new departure described in another column under the title "University Intension." The plan is especially significant
because of its possibilities.
Should the experience of the first year warrant it, no doubt the scope of the courses will
be widened. The advantage of this plan over
the culture courses that are carried on by correspondence and magazine articles, is in the
personal contact with the lecturers and the
acquaintance thus gained with University
methods. The men in charge of the 'movement are abundantly able to make it interesting, and it is safe to predict that the courses
will be widely appreciated.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
AFFAIRS OF A FORTNIGHT.
Hazing at Hopkins seems to have become
a tradition. This certainly ought to be a matter of thanksgiving to the Faculty--and to the
Freshmen. Whether the new Decalogue of
the President had a subduing effect on the
Juniors, or whether that class feels it got sufficient glory out of its hippodrome performance of last winter, does not appear. But
who can tell what a day may bring forth—or
a Freshman banquet!
The College 'Congress has convened. Junior M. C's and Senior 'Senators are expanding
with the Republic, while Freshmen are building political fences in anticipation of Congressional honors next year. That all of this
is part and parcel of a graded and required
three years' course in Public Speaking is a
happy and significant omen in our college life.
The making of such a course effective, and at
the same time interesting, has been a nut to
crack. With accustomed painstaking Johns
Hopkins seems to have hammered out the
kernel.
The policeman is a much abused factor in
the community. But there is a limit of endurance in every man's make-up. Rather
unfortunately two upper-classmen had to run
up against this limit the afternoon of the
Princeton-M. A. C. game. The Squire said
"two-fiff," and was immutable. Policemen
should not be imposed upon; still, the man
of the baton and brass buttons, with his high
order of intelligence, ought to recognize that
college men have certain rights and privileges
of citizenship extra ordinem, and that this is
especially true of Seniors. Of course, if there
must be a moral:
DON'T guy the cop.
The lunch-room has passed from the hands
of one Harris to the gentle keep of the
Woman's Industrial Exchange. The new
service, though somewhat primitive, is
prompt, and the fare is homelike .A few more

;

•

5

hot dishes on the calendar would be timely; a
modest oyster stew at popular prices would
help out wonderfully, for the cold lunch is a
real demoralizer to the average student's
stomach. Cold lunches and scholarship seem
not to be nearly related, but as old Dr. Johnson bluntly remarked (we thank thee, Boswell), "I look upon it, that he who does not
mind his belly will hardly mind anything
else."
There are some men about the University
who seem to get a good deal of satisfaction in
finding fault with—well, anything and everything. They are men who lounge at the cage
door, hands in pockets, and "damn" the athletes; the men who do not write for the NEWSLETTER, borrow another fellow's paper, and
criticize it; in brief, they are the chronic kickers. It is too bad. Such men call for our
commiseration. The cheerful thing to do is
to be happy. And the way to be happy is to
be up and doing, not fault-finding.
A course in public speaking has been arranged for the graduate students. They arc
to be congratulated. It is nothing new under
the sun: that university men are going into
professions and professorships without knowing how to talk. A platform lecture by a
flowering Ph. D. is too often eyed askance as
an evening of mental lassitude for the audience. Even class-room lectures have been
known to become wearisome! May the
words of the lusty old Poet-King early be
quoted for the graduate students: "Let me
hear thy voice, for thy voice is sweet."
The University Glee 'Club will hold its next
trial Thursday, ,October 27. At the preliminary meeting 28 candidates were present,
and the outlook is most encouraging. Some
time in November the final trials will be held,
and the club will be chosen. Mr. Louis
Fisher, leader of Fisher's orchestra, is directing the club, of which Mr. Karl Jungbluth is
leader.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLETICS.
FOOT BALL.

HOPKINS, 23; ROCKHILL, 0.
A crowd of about twenty-five rooters accompanied the football team to Ellicott City
on the 15th, and witnessed the first of the long
string of victories which the NEWS-LETTER
hopes to record for this year. Although it
was the opening game of the season, the team
made a good showing, aside from a tendency
to fumble, which several times gave the ball
to Rockhill.
After chasing a cow and other live stock
from the field, the teams lined up. Rockhill
kicked off, but Bouchelle fumbled, and was
downed on the 15-yard line. After a few
gains by the Hopkins backs, Rockhill lost io
yards on off-side play, and from this time the
ball was advanced steadily up the field. Hopkins kicked, and it was Rockhill's ball on their
m-yard line. Here our line demonstrated the
ease with which they could hold their opponents, as, after being pushed back 5 yards,
Rockhill lost the ball on downs. Here Hopkins fumbled, lost the ball on downs, and
Rockhill gained 40 yards. In the next few
minutes the ball changed hands frequently,
until finally Rockhill kicked out of bounds.
Hopkins now made steady gains, L. E. Griffin at last scoring a touchdown after a run of
30 yards. Hopkins punted out, but Mullen
missed the catch. Score, 5-0. After a few
minutes' more play the half ended, with the
ball in Rockhill's territory.
From this time on Hopkins proved that
they were in a class by themselves, as far as
Rockhill was concerned. After five minutes,
the ball was carried up the field by E. J. Griffin, until within three yards of the goal. At
this point Griffin was injured, but resumed his
place, and on the next play he carried the ball
across the line for a touchdown. Robinson
kicked goal. Score, 11-0.
Rockhill kicked off, and, after a long gain
by Mullen, Underwood left the game with an

injured knee. Hopkins was now gaining
steadily, and in a few minutes Guggenheimer
made another touchdown. Hopkins punted
out, and Robinson kicked goal.
Griffin and Guggenheimer were now given
the ball alternately, until it was far into Rockhill's territory, and then Robinson scored the
last touchdown, and once more kicked goal.
Score, 23-0.

HOPKINS, 0; D. A. C., 12.

I

The game played October 19 between Hopkins and the Druid Athletic Club resulted in
a surprise, especially to those not closely associated with either team. Attention has been
called to the fact that the team which played
for D. A. C. was composed of men from no
less than three local organizations, in which
respect it is said the rules of the Amateur
Athletic Union suffered fracture. At all
events, they had a well-balanced team, which
put up a good game, making very few bad
plays. The best work was done by Lawrence
and Lee.
The Hopkins team, though good in places,
for the most part played very poorly. The
backs missed the ball almost every time it was
passed to them. The line, too, was very weak
at times, and should have gotten into the game
in much better style. A few men, among
them Robinson, Smith and Guggenheimer,
did good work for Hopkins.

THE MASS MEETINGS.

A meeting of the General Athletic Association was held on October 13, in Hopkins
Hall. The president of the Association, Dr.
Renouf, presided. Nominations for the offices to be filled at the annual elections were
made, and a number of amendments to the
Constitution were proposed by Mr. R. H.
Grimes. These were posted for a week, and
after an outline had been given of the more
important matters to come up before the Association during the year, the meeting adjourned.
On the 2ist another meeting was held. The
amendments to the Constitution were unanimously adopted. They provide that the board
of directors shall consist of a member from the
faculty, who shall have the power of absolute
veto; of one delegate each from the graduate
department and the Medical School; of an
alumnus, not at present a member of the
University; and of a secretary and a treasurer. The seniors are to have two delegates
to the board, the juniors two, and the freshmen one. All of these are to be elected at a
mass meeting to be held prior to October 15
of each year. At this first meeting all members of the University shall have the right to
vote; at the subsequent meetings, only members of the Association. Another amendment provides that no one shall hold two of
the offices of the Association, which are open
to popular election.
The elections resulted as follows: Faculty
member, Dr. Rcnouf; president, William H.
Maddren ; vice-president, Thomas Fitzgerald;
secretary, Z. M. Ballard; treasurer, R. T.
Abercrombie; graduate, G. L. Radcliffe; Medical School, C. W. Ottley; alumnus, Mr. Wm.
Hilles, '89; class delegates, '99, Grimes and
Knapp; two, Schriver and Wirt; 1901,
Diggs.
For a long time past there has been need of
more effective cheering by supporters of the
various teams. The importance of this can
hardly be overestimated as an incentive to the
men in the field to work and win games.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

There has been no organized yelling for a long
time. It was in recognition of these facts
a motion was made and carried, without a dissenting voice, that Mr. Stephen Harwood
should be appointed "Chief Rooter," or leader
of cheering.
CLASS ELECTIONS.

The undergraduates have elected class officers for the new year. John C. French was
named as president by the Seniors, with
Henry Bogue as vice-president; John R.
Gemmil, treasurer; Walter M. Krager, secretary; Geo. D. Davidson, poet. French led his
class in the junior year, was elected editor-inchief of The Hullabaloo, and is editor-in-chief
of the NEWS-LETTER.
Christopher T. Clark, of Washington,
elected president of the Junior Class, has been
active in athletics as a runner and distance
juniper. John P. Hill was chosen vice-president; Howard Baetjer, secretary; Ronald T.
Abercrombie, treasurer; William P. Shriver,
historian, and Carol Wight, class poet. Executive committee: James L. A. Burrell,
Harry Wright, Alex. Van R. Schermerhorn,
James H. Brady, Jr., T. N. DeL. Purcell.
S. H. Byrne, elected president of the Freshman Class, graduated from the City College,
where he was prominent as a leader and organizer of the athletic interests. He is the
University correspondent for the American.
The remaining officers of the class will be
chosen at a forthcoming meeting.
HENRY P. MUTER.

Henry P. Shuter, '97, a member of the famous Astor Mountain Battery of Volunteers,
died at sea, October 17, on the transport Rio
de Janeiro, returning from Manila. Of splendid physique, Ile was the fourth selected from
400 candidates for enlistment in a competitive
examination. Three days after the battle of
Manila he wrote that his battery had served
as General Merritt's body guard, and that he
had fought in the front ranks. Sinner was a
popular man in his class; played on the 'Varsity football team, and was editor-in-chief of
the '97 Hullabaloo.

INTERCESSIONAL.

Board of our fathers known of old—
Board of the sons that have gone before—
Beneath whose awful hand we hold
Degrees and scholarships galore—
Be with us yet—be with us yet,
Lest we forget—lest we forget.
"A. B.'s" and "Ph. D.'s" depart
To try their fate for good or bad—
Still stands thine ancient sacrifice,
An humble, contrite "Prep-school" lad.
Judge of the "Sub-fresh," spare us yet,
Lest we forget—lest we forget.
From the Registrar we wend our way—
He's dimmed the goal of our desire—
Lo! all our hopes of yesterday
Are one with Nineveh and Tyre.
Board of our fathers, spare us yet,
Lest we forget—lest we forget.
If, after having passed, we loose
Wild tongues that have not thee in awe,
Such language as the Seniors use,
Or lesser breeds, who know no law—
Be with us yet—be with us yet,
Lest we forget—lest we forget.
For frantic head that puts its trust
In "cramming" and through "cribs" has
soared,
And, passing, calls not thee to pass,
Thy mercy on thy victims, Board.
Amen.
1901.
A QUANDARY.

For weal or woe—
Which shall it be?
With one, a-cycling I may go
For weal or woe;
A horse doth bring another beau
To ride with me;
For wheel or whoa—
Which shall it be?
